questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presents with a history of multiple craniofacial anomalies, including downward slanting eyes, and small jaw. The mother informs that the child had recurrent middle ear infections and has a history of hearing loss. Examination reveals a high-arched palate and respiratory difficulty due to upper airway obstruction. Imaging studies demonstrate hypoplasia of mandible with malocclusion and absence of the zygomatic arch. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features, radiological findings and the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Treacher Collins Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Down Syndrome: Characterized by intellectual disability , distinct facial features (flat facial profile, slanted eyes, small ears), and other systemic manifestations . The specific craniofacial and radiological findings described do not typically align with Down Syndrome.
  • • Option B. Down Syndrome:
  • • intellectual disability
  • • distinct facial features
  • • systemic manifestations
  • • Option C. Seckel Syndrome: Known for primordial dwarfism , microcephaly , and a "bird-like" face , which does not specifically include the craniofacial anomalies or hearing issues described in the question.
  • • Option C. Seckel Syndrome:
  • • primordial dwarfism
  • • microcephaly
  • • "bird-like" face
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome: Affects females and involves a missing or partially missing X chromosome , leading to short stature, gonadal dysgenesis , and other physical abnormalities, but not typically the craniofacial anomalies described for TCS.
  • • Option D. Turner Syndrome:
  • • females and involves a missing or partially missing X chromosome
  • • short stature, gonadal dysgenesis
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 th Edition, Page No 7613
  • • Ref: Nelson 21 th Edition, Page No 7613

questions.text: A working mother brings her 3-year-old child to the pediatrician’s office for a routine check-up. On evaluation child is small for her age with a beak-like nose, narrow face, and widely spaced eyes as shown in the image. The mother reports that the child has difficulty feeding due to a small jaw and mouth, and has been slow to reach developmental milestones. The pediatrician diagnoses this as a case of Seckel syndrome. All of the following are features of Seckel syndrome, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Macrocephaly

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A, C and D are the features of Seckel syndrome.
  • • Seckel syndrome.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seckel (SCKL) syndrome , sometimes called “bird-headed dwarfism,” is an autosomal recessive developmental disorder characterized by marked growth failure and mental deficiency, microcephaly , a hypoplastic face with a prominent nose , and low-set and/or malformed ears. Approximately 25% of patients have aplastic anemia or malignancies.
  • ➤ Seckel
  • ➤ syndrome
  • ➤ “bird-headed dwarfism,”
  • ➤ autosomal recessive developmental disorder
  • ➤ marked growth failure
  • ➤ mental deficiency, microcephaly
  • ➤ hypoplastic face with a prominent nose
  • ➤ low-set and/or malformed ears.
  • ➤ Note - There is broad genetic heterogeneity comprising at least 8 classifiable types: SCKL1, ATR mutation; SCKL2, RBBP8 mutation; SCKL3, maps to 14q21-q22; SCKL4, CENPJ mutation; SCKL5, CEP152 mutation; SCKL6, CEP63 mutation; SCKL7, NIN mutation; and SCKL8, ATRIP mutation.

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn to the hospital for a procedure, as shown in the image. The child has a history of hyperbilirubinemia. The infant is placed under a type of light as part of the treatment. Which mechanism is chiefly responsible for the reduction in the levels of serum bilirubin during the procedure depicted?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Structural isomerization

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Photooxidation: This is a minor reaction , where, photoproducts are excreted in urine .
  • • Option A. Photooxidation:
  • • minor reaction
  • • photoproducts are excreted in urine
  • • Option B. Photoisomerization: This term refers to the light-induced conversion of bilirubin to a different isomer , specifically converting the Z, Z-bilirubin to the more polar E,Z-bilirubin and E,E-bilirubin isomers . These isomers are more water-soluble and can be excreted without conjugation. It is is one of the mechanisms by which the phototherapy acts whereas the main mechanism is Structural isomerization.
  • • Option B. Photoisomerization:
  • • light-induced conversion
  • • bilirubin
  • • different isomer
  • • converting the Z, Z-bilirubin
  • • more polar E,Z-bilirubin
  • • E,E-bilirubin isomers
  • • Structural isomerization.
  • • Option D. Conjugation: Conjugation is a liver process where bilirubin is made water-soluble by adding a glucuronic acid molecule , allowing it to be excreted in bile . This is not the process used by phototherapy to reduce bilirubin; rather, it is the natural metabolic pathway that may be deficient in newborns, leading to hyperbilirubinemia.
  • • Option D. Conjugation:
  • • liver process
  • • bilirubin is made water-soluble
  • • adding a glucuronic acid molecule
  • • excreted in bile
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Phototherapy remains the mainstay of treating hyperbilirubinemia in neonates. It acts by converting insoluble bilirubin (unconjugated) into soluble isomers that can be excreted in urine and feces . The bilirubin molecule isomerizes to harmless forms under blue-green light (460-490 nm). Structural isomerization is mainly responsible for phototherapy induced decline in TSB .
  • • Phototherapy remains the mainstay
  • • treating hyperbilirubinemia in neonates.
  • • converting insoluble bilirubin
  • • soluble isomers
  • • excreted in urine and feces
  • • bilirubin molecule isomerizes
  • • harmless forms
  • • blue-green light (460-490 nm). Structural isomerization
  • • phototherapy induced decline in TSB
  • • Ref - OP Ghai 9 th Edition Page No- 171.
  • • Ref
  • • -
  • • OP Ghai 9 th Edition Page No- 171.

questions.text: In a primary health center, a 26-year-old woman with an unknown date of her last menstrual period gives birth to a baby weighing 2100 grams. The healthcare team faces the challenge of assessing the newborn's maturity to ensure the provision of appropriate neonatal care. Given the absence of prenatal history for a newborn weighing 2100 grams at birth, which of the following sign should be evaluated by the healthcare team to determine the newborn's gestational maturity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Ear cartilage form and firmness: The development and firmness of the ear cartilage can indicate gestational maturity , with less mature neonates having softer , less well-defined cartilage.
  • • Option A. Ear cartilage form and firmness:
  • • development
  • • firmness of the ear cartilage
  • • gestational maturity
  • • less mature neonates having softer
  • • Option B. Arm recoiling: This neuromuscular maturity indicator involves flexing the neonate's arm at the elbow and then releasing it . The speed and extent to which the arm returns to its flexed position can help assess neuromuscular development and, by extension, gestational age .
  • • Option B. Arm recoiling:
  • • neuromuscular maturity indicator
  • • flexing the neonate's arm
  • • elbow
  • • then releasing it
  • • speed and extent
  • • arm returns to its flexed position
  • • help assess neuromuscular development
  • • extension, gestational age
  • • Option C. Plantar crease: The presence and depth of creases on the soles of the feet are used as a physical maturity indicator . More and deeper creases are generally associated with higher gestational age.
  • • Option C. Plantar crease:
  • • presence and depth of creases
  • • soles of the feet
  • • physical maturity indicator

questions.text: A 3-year-old, previously healthy child, is brought to the clinic by their mother due to a complaint of foul-smelling discharge from the left side of the nose. Examination reveals unilateral nasal obstruction and a foul-smelling discharge. Upon further examination, an object is seen in the nasal cavity, as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Foreign body

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atrophic Rhinitis : This is a chronic condition characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and is uncommon in young children .
  • • Option A. Atrophic Rhinitis
  • • chronic condition
  • • atrophy of the nasal mucosa
  • • uncommon in young children
  • • Option B. Nasal Polyposis : Nasal polyps are typically bilateral and not usually associated with a foul smell . They are also rare in this age group.
  • • Option B. Nasal Polyposis
  • • bilateral
  • • not
  • • associated with a foul smell
  • • Option D. Septal Deviation : This structural issue typically does not cause a foul-smelling discharge and is usually not diagnosed in such young children unless associated with trauma or congenital malformation.
  • • Option D. Septal Deviation
  • • structural issue
  • • does not cause a foul-smelling discharge

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key indicators of a nasal foreign body include unilateral nasal obstruction , foul-smelling discharge , and the visualization of an object in the nasal cavity . Prompt recognition and removal of the foreign body are essential to prevent complications such as infection and further obstruction.
  • ➤ nasal foreign body include unilateral nasal obstruction
  • ➤ foul-smelling discharge
  • ➤ visualization of an object
  • ➤ nasal cavity
  • ➤ Ref: Nelson 21 st Edition page no 8739-8744

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child presenting with complaints of high fever, severe sore throat, difficulty swallowing, drooling, and inspiratory stridor. On examination, the child appears anxious, has a muffled voice, and the following appearance. Based on these findings given, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Acute epiglottitis

Explanation:

  • • fever
  • • enlarged tonsils
  • • Option D. Acute pharyngitis presents with sore throat , fever , and enlarged lymph nodes , but lacks the drooling, inspiratory stridor, and cherry-red epiglottis seen in acute epiglottitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with a history of cyanotic heart disease is brought to the pediatric surgery outpatient department by their mother. The pediatric surgeon conducts a thorough examination and then engages in a teaching moment with the residents, discussing the various shunt surgeries available for managing such conditions. The surgeon presents several options and asks the residents to identify which statement about shunt surgeries is incorrect, emphasizing the need for precision in understanding and choosing the appropriate surgical intervention.

options.label: A
options.text: Waterson’s shunt: Right PA is joined to ascending aorta

options.label: B
options.text: Pott’s shunt: Left PA is joined to descending aorta

options.label: C
options.text: Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt: Subclavian artery is joined to pulmonary artery

options.label: D
options.text: Pott’s shunt: Left PA is joined to ascending aorta.

questions.correct_answer: D. Pott’s shunt: Left PA is joined to ascending aorta.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Waterson’s shunt : This is accurate as it describes connecting the right pulmonary artery to the ascending aorta , a method used to augment pulmonary blood flow in specific heart conditions.
  • • Option A. Waterson’s shunt
  • • connecting the right pulmonary artery
  • • ascending aorta
  • • augment pulmonary blood flow
  • • Option B. Pott’s shunt : This correctly identifies the traditional Pott’s shunt connection between the left pulmonary artery and the descending aorta .
  • • Option B. Pott’s shunt
  • • traditional Pott’s shunt connection
  • • left pulmonary artery
  • • descending aorta
  • • Option C. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt : This accurately describes the connection between the subclavian artery and the pulmonary artery , a common procedure to increase pulmonary blood flow in cyanotic heart diseases.
  • • Option C. Modified Blalock-Taussig Shunt
  • • connection between the subclavian artery
  • • pulmonary artery

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient pediatric department by his mother, who expresses concerns that her son might have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). She describes him as being extremely restless at home, having a persistent inability to focus on tasks, and frequently misplacing his belongings. Despite these concerns, the child appears cooperative during the visit and his physical examination does not reveal any abnormalities. The mother is eager for advice on how to manage her son's symptoms and improve his ability to concentrate and remain organized. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication

options.label: B
options.text: Obtain further information from the parents and teachers

options.label: C
options.text: Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate

options.label: D
options.text: Send the child for psychological assessment

questions.correct_answer: B. Obtain further information from the parents and teachers
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obtain further information from the parents and teachers.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication - Starting medication without a thorough assessment and definitive diagnosis is inappropriate . Stimulant medications are a mainstay in the treatment of ADHD but should only be considered after a comprehensive evaluation confirms the diagnosis.
  • • Option A. Give the child a 2-week trial of stimulant medication
  • • Starting medication without a thorough assessment
  • • definitive diagnosis is inappropriate
  • • Option C . Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate - While some level of inattention and restlessness can be normal for children , the mother's concerns and the description of the child's behavior warrant a thorough evaluation to rule out ADHD or other disorders.
  • • Option C
  • • Reassure the child’s mother that this behavior is age appropriate
  • • some level of inattention
  • • restlessness
  • • normal for children
  • • Option D. Send the child for psychological assessment - While a psychological assessment may be part of the evaluation process for ADHD , the initial step should involve gathering detailed information from those who observe the child in various settings. If the initial information supports the possibility of ADHD, a more in-depth psychological assessment might then be warranted.
  • • Option D.
  • • Send the child for psychological assessment
  • • psychological assessment
  • • part of the evaluation process for ADHD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial approach to evaluate a child suspected of having ADHD - Comprehensive evaluation including obtaining a detailed information from parents and teachers , is essential before considering a diagnosis of ADHD and discussing treatment options. This ensures that any intervention is based on a thorough understanding of the child's behaviors across different environments.
  • ➤ The initial approach to evaluate a child suspected of having ADHD
  • ➤ Comprehensive evaluation
  • ➤ detailed information from parents and teachers
  • ➤ Ref : O P Ghai 9 th Edition Page No- 56-59
  • ➤ Ref :
  • ➤ O P Ghai 9 th Edition Page No- 56-59

questions.text: An infant girl is born prematurely at 29 weeks of gestation due to an incompetent cervix and undergoes spontaneous vaginal delivery. Given the risks associated with prematurity, the neonate is closely monitored and admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Which aspect of her clinical course in the NICU is most likely to correlate with her long-term clinical outcome five years in the future?
questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS):
  • • Option A. Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS):
  • • Description : RDS is a common respiratory complication in preterm infants due to immature lungs , leading to difficulty breathing. Significance : While RDS can have immediate implications, its severity may not always be the strongest predictor of long-term outcomes .
  • • Description : RDS is a common respiratory complication in preterm infants due to immature lungs , leading to difficulty breathing.
  • • Description

  • • severity may not
  • • strongest predictor of long-term outcomes
  • • Option C. Apnea of Prematurity:
  • • Option C. Apnea of Prematurity:
  • • Description : Apnea of prematurity is a temporary cessation of breathing for >20 seconds in preterm infants due to immature respiratory centers in the brain. Significance : While apnea is significant in the neonatal period, its correlation with long-term outcomes may not be as direct as with certain neurological complications.
  • • Description : Apnea of prematurity is a temporary cessation of breathing for >20 seconds in preterm infants due to immature respiratory centers in the brain.

Significance : ROP , especially in its early stages , may not be as strongly correlated with long-term neurodevelopmental outcomes compared to severe intraventricular hemorrhage .

questions.text: A mother brings her newborn to the clinic, concerned about the baby's head, which appears enlarged and features visible veins. The physician, after evaluating the newborn, determines that the baby's condition is due to a disruption in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to accumulation. While discussing the diagnosis and implications with the family, the mother's sister inquires about normal CSF production in a child. What is the normal rate of CSF production in a child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 20 mL/hr

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • The normal rate of CSF production in a child is approximately 20 mL/hr . CSF is produced by the choroid plexuses located in the ventricles of the brain and the rate remains relatively constant . This production leads to a total turnover of CSF about three to four times per day in both children and adults.
  • • 20 mL/hr
  • • choroid plexuses
  • • ventricles of the brain
  • • relatively constant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The normal production of CSF in an infant is 20 mL/hr.
  • ➤ The normal production of CSF in an infant is 20 mL/hr.
  • ➤ Overproduction or under excretion , resulting from an obstruction in the CSF flow pathway will result in Hydrocephalus.
  • ➤ Overproduction or under excretion
  • ➤ Hydrocephalus.
  • ➤ Ref : OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.
  • ➤ Ref : OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-578.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male visits the pediatric department with symptoms of weight gain, fatigue, increased sensitivity to cold, dry skin, and facial puffiness, leading to a diagnosis of hypothyroidism. During the consultation, the child exhibits difficulties in understanding, prompting an ENT consultation. On Pure Tone Audiometry the following Graph is obtained and there was a mutation in Cl-Iodine transporter. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pendred Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation

  • • Option A. Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  • • Option B. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis : Refers to a group of disorders causing hypothyroidism due to enzymatic defects in thyroid hormone synthesis, but not usually linked to hearing loss.
  • • Option B. Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • • Option D. Graves' disease : An autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism, and not associated with hearing loss.
  • • Option D. Graves' disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Pendred Syndrome is due to mutation in the PDS gene on 7 th chromosome which codes for Chloride/Iodide transporter. The features of Pendred syndrome are Sensory Neural Hearing Loss ( SNHL ) along with goitre and hypothyroidism.
  • ➤ PDS gene
  • ➤ 7 th chromosome
  • ➤ SNHL
  • ➤ hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old working mother in a multinational company brings her 3-month-old infant to your clinic for a routine pediatric visit. After returning to work postpartum, she expresses a desire to transition her baby from breast milk to cow's milk due to her busy schedule. She inquires about the nutritional differences between human milk and cow's milk, specifically asking which component is present in higher quantities in human milk compared to cow's milk. Which of the following is the correct response?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Lactose

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Calcium: Cow's milk actually contains higher levels of calcium than human milk . However, the bioavailability of calcium in human milk is better, meaning infants can absorb it more efficiently.

  • • contains higher levels of calcium than human milk
  • • Option C. Protein: Cow's milk contains a higher concentration of total protein than human milk . The protein composition in cow's milk is also different, which can be harder for infants to digest and may lead to an increased risk of allergic reactions.
  • • Option C. Protein:
  • • higher concentration of total protein than human milk
  • • Option D. Fat: While the total fat content may be similar in both human and cow's milk , the composition of fat in human milk is uniquely suited to the human infant's needs, including essential fatty acids crucial for brain development that are not present in cow's milk in the same ratios.

  • • total fat content may be similar in both human

questions.text: A concerned mother presents to the pediatric clinic with her child, who has experienced 7 episodes of loose stools from morning till evening. Upon examination, the pediatrician notes mild dehydration in the child. Considering the clinical presentation and the need for rehydration, which of the following is the most appropriate initial fluid choice for managing diarrhea in this infant?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ORS

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Salt Water: While rehydration requires salt , salt water alone is not recommended due to its high sodium concentration , which can worsen dehydration and lead to hypernatremia.
  • • Option A. Salt Water:
  • • rehydration requires salt
  • • salt water
  • • high sodium concentration
  • • worsen dehydration
  • • lead to hypernatremia.
  • • Option B. Sugar Water: Sugar water can provide some energy but lacks the necessary electrolytes needed to correct the electrolyte imbalances caused by diarrhea . It is not sufficient for rehydration purposes.
  • • Option B. Sugar Water:
  • • provide some energy but lacks the necessary electrolytes
  • • correct the electrolyte imbalances
  • • diarrhea
  • • Option D. Normal Saline: Normal Saline is an intravenous solution that can be used in more severe cases of dehydration or when oral rehydration is not possible . However, for mild dehydration and when oral intake is feasible, ORS is preferred due to its ease of use and effectiveness in promoting intestinal water and electrolyte absorption.
  • • Option D. Normal Saline:
  • • intravenous solution
  • • used in more severe cases of dehydration
  • • oral rehydration is not possible

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) is the recommended first-line treatment for rehydration in infants and children with mild to moderate dehydration due to diarrhea . ORS is specifically formulated to contain the ideal balance of salts and sugars to facilitate water absorption in the intestine.
  • ➤ Oral Rehydration Solution
  • ➤ first-line treatment for rehydration
  • ➤ infants
  • ➤ children
  • ➤ mild to moderate dehydration
  • ➤ diarrhea

questions.text: A mother brings her 6-year-old child to a local clinic with concerns about the child's noticeably distended abdomen and a history of recurrent infections. Upon physical examination, the child exhibits notable pallor and splenomegaly. The physical examination findings of the child revealed the following image. Additionally, an X-ray of the skull shows abnormal bone structure with a "crew cut" appearance, indicative of bone marrow expansion. A peripheral blood smear reveals microcytic hypochromic red blood cells and target cells. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the diagnosis?

options.label: C
options.text: Iron supplements are indicated in the management of the disease

options.label: D
options.text: The child may require blood transfusions

  • • Option B.
  • • The child is at risk of developing gallstones
  • • True
  • • Option D. The child may require blood transfusions : True , patients with beta-thalassemia major often require regular blood transfusions to manage severe anemia.
  • • Option D.
  • • The child may require blood transfusions
  • • True

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta-thalassemia can present with facial bone deformities , splenomegaly , and specific blood smear findings . Management often involves regular blood transfusions , while iron supplementation is not typically indicated due to the risk of iron overload.

questions.text: A midwife at a PHC is monitoring pregnancy and maintaining the WHO modified partograph of pregnancy progression. At how much cervical dilation should the partograph plotting be started?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 4 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor. It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention. In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated. In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line) Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Partograph is a graphical representation of progress of labor, which is depicted using cervical dilatation and descent of head against the duration of labor.
  • ➤ It is used for early detection of abnormal labor patterns for timely intervention.
  • ➤ In a partograph the active phase of labor starts when the cervix is 4 cm dilated.
  • ➤ In active phase, cervix should dilate at the rate of 1 cm/hr. (Alert Line)
  • ➤ Partograph has two lines for assessment of progression of dilation Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate) A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Alert line: Alert line starts at 4 cm cervical dilation & ends with full dilation of the cervix (10 cm) in 7 hours (1 cm/hour dilation rate)
  • ➤ A ction line: Action line is drawn four hours to the right of the alert line. If action line is crossed while plotting the progression, it indicates need for urgent intervention.
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm
  • ➤ Remember that in the modified partograph, plotting starts at 4 cm onward, and the 1 st mark is always put on the alert line
  • ➤ If asked, when does plotting start in the Labor care guide (Next generation partograph), then the answer is 5cm

questions.text: According to WHO guidelines on management of labor, which of the following is true about management of second stage of labor?

options.label: B
options.text: Episiotomy should be performed as a routine

options.label: C
options.text: A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Delivery should be ideally performed in a lithotomy position

questions.correct_answer: C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. A warm cloth should be applied to the perineum to prevent trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO recommendations of 2018,
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ As per WHO guidelines on intrapartum care for a positive birth experience (2018), these are the recommendations in 2 nd stage
  • ➤ Definition and duration of the second stage of labor: The second stage is the period of time between full cervical dilatation and birth of the baby, during which the woman has an involuntary urge to bear down, as a result of expulsive uterine contractions. In first labors, birth is usually completed within 3 hours whereas in subsequent labors, birth is usually completed within 2 hours. Recommended Birth position (for women with or without epidural analgesia) For women without epidural analgesia, encouraging the adoption of a birth position of the individual woman’s choice, including upright positions, is recommended. Method of pushing Women in the expulsive phase of the second stage of labor should be encouraged and supported to follow their own urge to push. Method of pushing (for women with epidural analgesia) For women with epidural analgesia in the second stage of labor, delaying pushing for one to two hours after full dilatation or until the woman regains the sensory urge to bear down is recommended in the context where resources are available for longer stay in second stage and perinatal hypoxia can be adequately assessed and managed. Techniques for preventing perineal trauma. For women in the second stage of labor, techniques to reduce perineal trauma and facilitate spontaneous birth (including perineal massage, warm compresses and a “hands on” guarding of the perineum) are recommended, based on a woman’s preferences and available options. Episiotomy policy Routine or liberal use of episiotomy is not recommended for women undergoing spontaneous vaginal birth. Fundal pressure Application of manual fundal pressure to facilitate childbirth during the second stage of labor is not recommended.

  • ➤ There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:
  • ➤ Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts) The 1 st pelvic grip (3 rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation. The 2 nd pelvic grip (4 th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.
